"In recent centuries, philosophers in fact have discovered how to weigh that allegorical fish, in various fields, and on each occasion a new discipline has been born: physics in the 17th century; chemistry in the 18th; biology in the 19th and psychology in the 20th."

What is the basis for saying this?

The magnetic compass (invented in China) did far more for the Standard Model and General Theory of Relativity than 2000 years of Western natural philosophy. Gilbert used the compass to show that the Earth was a magnet, and speculated that planets could attract each other. Kepler picked up that idea in Astronomia Nova as a possible explanation for the changes in the speed of planets in their orbits. Newton later provided the mathematics of universal gravitation. The compass needle pops again in an accidental observation that electrical currents alter magnetic fields. Maxwell provided the mathematics for the relationship between the two and realized that light was an electromagnetic wave. Einstein published his special theory of relativity in a paper on The Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies to solve a problem in Maxwell's equations for moving observers. When he generalized it to include bodies accelerating under gravity he developed the General Theory of Relativity. His Nobel Prize-winning paper on the photoelectric effect kicked off the idea of wave particle duality, and so quantum mechanics, quantum electrodynamics and the Standard Model.

Where did the philosophers come in?

Magic thinking is endemic to humanity. We can hope that reason will bring us to our senses sooner rather than later, but on the whole the evidence is pointing the other way.

I find your perspective illuminating, but, as someone who is having an FET tomorrow with, yes, a young woman's egg and my husband's sperm, I am thankful for this opportunity. I don't feel as though the clinic we are working with does this lightly; they know their patients come to them at the end of the line, hopeful and resolved. We looked into adoption, and found most routes closed to us. We tried IUI, IVF. We tried thinking of a future "child free." I don't know what you mean by "nefarious," but, the women (and their partners) who go through the years of gambling, praying, trying to have a child would not go through the process of having a child via any form of ART for "nefarious" purposes.

Domestic adoption is not for everyone - it's rightfully up to the mother/parents to choose a family, and some of us are simply not the right age, cultural mix, etc. to have a good chance of being selected.

Very well said.  I'm taken aback by the vilification of surrogacy process in so many of the comments here.  Women should be allowed to have all choices for their bodies: to have babies, to not have babies and (in very rare cases) to choose to have babies for couples who desperately want children.

We forget that a surrogate is a real woman able and willing to conceive for somone else. Mankind is not yet at the point of creating offspring in a laboratory. With the goal of making everyone equal,  it still takes a male and a female to create a life.

Whether or not a surrogate is willing to have an abortion in the event of a severe problem with the fetus should be discussed and agreed upon before the surrogacy takes place.  If the surrogate is not willing to consider/have an abortion, then the woman should not be a surrogate in the first place.  What about the opposite situation where the parents want the surrogate to carry the pregnancy with a severe problem to term and she does not or feels that it will hurt her health.  All of this needs to be discussed/agreed upon up front.  Life is complicated.  We can not control everything, so there are going to be situations where people make a decision that not everyone will agree with.  The woman who didn't want a baby with a cleft brain would have probably have made the same decisions (abortion/putting the child up for adoption) if she had been the birth mother and had not used a surrogate.

worldwide...I don't think surrogacy effects any population statistics, societal norms or anything at all. Its a fringe event that most of the time provides something good for all involved. As far as I can reason, most babies will still be born the usual way. No need to hit panic buttons or start hating on one another.

One last point:  it is perfectly possible to "commission" babies that contain none of the buyer's DNA, just an egg from column A, some sperm off column B, cooked up in womb C and delivered to the writer of big checks.  It is most likely being done right now.  Baby production as an utterly depersonalized boutique industry.  I'm sure the final products could have a high resale value to people who didn't want to wait nine months.  Ick.

Follow your logic out to its logical conclusion (pun intended-apologies to Richard Pryor). Since you put it in your post, I'll assume you like the superficial reasoning of "...popular definitions of insanity is, roughly, doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results..." But again, follow the logic of all this...why does one expect capitalism to "work"? The results we're seeing are the results we've always seen, only they are far worse in the Third World (formerly known as colonies). Hence we have the mass imprisonment of children attempting escape from those conditions. That's one example of "the system works!" and the ramifications of that.

But here's a question: name one country whose economy actually grew during the entirety of Great Depression of the 1930s? You won't like the answer. Hint: it's leader is presented as the devil incarnate. Hint #2, read the question carefully. Its wording rules out Germany.

You think that, I think that...

But people who made only 500 times what their employees made years ago but now make 2500 times as much, people who gamble and produce nothing but are awarded multi-million dollar bonuses and are sore if they're not higher, and those who earn their quarterly bonuses for firing people and eliminating jobs, would have the story differently: for that class things have worked out as expected, and very well.

Unfortunately, the only thing we can do to counter demonstrably wrongheaded faith-based economics is to show how evidence-based economics has proven to be right. Worse than unfortunately, the people we most need to convince--those who attempt to undercut the legitimacy of the latter--are not persuaded by evidence.

I believe one of the popular definitions of insanity is, roughly, doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results. We've had over three decades of tax-cutting, government-slashing dogma that has been proven wrong most every time, and devotees of this school of thought are not willing to give up the ghost for another few decades at least. That's highly alarming. And insane.

I don't buy this analogy to physics about added money being stored energy. First off, the Fed buying assets is not strictly money printing - it is an asset swap. Second, money velocity can increase or decrease regardless of whether there is money printing (or asset swapping) or not. There are plenty of examples in economic history to support this, including the most recent 2008 bubble that Krugman cites.
One benefit of the asset swap is that many people still get to stay in their (albeit distressed) homes. But maybe you think that is not such a great benefit? I agree, however, that the banks got off easy because of this.
And if there is actual inflation, monetary policy can be adjusted to deal with it. It makes more sense to deal with actual problems rather then what might happen in the future.

So when do you expect this inflation surge.  I can't wait forever on you -- I may die first.  You sound like the guys who sell books predicting the stock market crash of 2012, then 2013, now 2014.  Someday the market will do down as it always does, and these folks will take credit for the "crash".  And some day inflation will go up somewhat, and you'll say, "See, see."

The ballooning Fed balance sheet (money printing) is adding energy into the system (economy). Prof Krugman is correct that, at the moment, that energy is stored (suppressed), as opposed to flowing through the economy.

So we have energy (extra dollars) but not (yet) increased money velocity (inflation). The reasons are many. Banks and individuals are using the extra supply of money to rebuild their own balance sheets, rather than loaning out and spending it.

But make no mistake, there is a lot of latent energy in the system. Just like a warm and humid day. Not every hot/humid day spawns thunderstorms. But the chance of thunderstorms is much increased in such conditions.

So to with our economy. Money printing doesn't lead to high inflation in each case, but it greatly increases the chances of it.

So, for many conservatives, taking that risk is only warranted if the benefits are worth the gamble. Prof. Krugman has yet to tell us what the great benefit to the US economy has been to go from $0.8T to $4.0T in Fed assets. Sure, banks are making a killing, and the stock market is inflated, and we may have reduced long term interest rates in some small way. But what was the big net benefit to the economy that justifies the risk of all this extra potential energy?
